course.course_description: The Television Writing Intensive is a six week, concentrated and encompassing introduction into the field of television writing, designed to prepare students for the professional worlds of sit-coms, one-hour dramas and police / medical procedurals.  In an interconnected program consisting of two intensive writing workshops and a lecture series with guest writers and professionals in the field, students gain the knowledge and authority to explore, examine and create the kind of groundbreaking work that is taking over cable and making its way onto the Networks, here and around the world. The Television Writing Intensive focuses on two specific tracks.  One track is the half-hour comedy; the other is the one-hour drama. These two formats, although having much in common, come out of different traditions and are conceived and written in different ways. * This intensive course will meet 15 hours per week, on Mondays and Tuesdays for six hours during the day (exact times TBD), and Thursday evenings for three hours (exact time TBD).  These times are probable but subject to change based on availability of guest speakers and other opportunities which may arise, but the general format will stay the same if changes do occur.  Meaning, the course will meet for two week days for six hours and one week night for three hours, avoiding Fridays, Saturdays, and Sundays.

course.course_description: Conceived and designed by the faculty of the SoA graduate Film Program, this hands-on workshop will focus on the narrative/dramatic filmmaking form. Each participant will learn to write an original short film and then transform that text to the screen. Emphasis will be placed on the director's textual analysis of the screenplay, on blocking actors, and on the camera as narrator. The instructor will assign the first dialogue film; the student will write the second. All films will be 3-5 minutes.

course.course_name: Introduction to the Study and Theory of Film
course.course_description: The nature of cinema as a technology, a business, a cultural product, an entertainment medium, and most especially an art form. Study of cinematic genres, stylistics, and nationalities; outstanding film artists and artisans; the relationship of cinema to other art forms and media, as well as to society.

course.course_name: Introduction To the Study and Theory of Film
course.course_description: Lecture and discussion. Priority given to declared film majors. Fee: $75. Basic principles of film study--film aesthetics (mise-en-scene, cinematography, editing, sound); film history (interaction of historical, economic, ideological, and technological determinants); film theory (realism, cinema specificity, relationship of film to other arts); and film criticism (feminist, Marxist, structuralist, semiotic, psychoanalytic, auteurist, and generic approaches).

course.course_description: Fee: $75. Priority given to film majors. A survey of masterpieces of the American sound film with a focus on genres including the gangster film, Western, screwball comedy, and musical. Personal directorial styles and cultural contexts are explored in the work of Hawks, Ford, Welles, Lubitsch, Kazan, Wilder, and Kubrick.
Fee: $75. Priority given to film majors and seniors. American Film History beginning in l960.

Fee: $75. Survey of the early history of film aesthetics and technology, including the impact of Griffith and Eisenstein, German Expressionism, the French avant-garde, the consolidation of Hollywood, the relationship between film and theatre, changing approaches to performance, and the place of women and minorities in early cinema.

This course will examine American cinema in the “digital age.” The introduction of digital technology –as a means of production, distribution and exhibition—will be explored in light of changes in narrative style, use of genre, film financing and the place of cinema within American culture and society. Special attention will be paid to the interaction between the mainstream, studio produced or distributed cinema and the emerging independent cinema. Directors whose works will be discussed include Martin Scorsese, David Lynch, and Clint Eastwood.

The evolution of the horror genre.  Horror films provide compelling commentary on the deep-seated and frequently unspoken public and private trepidation that accompanies any cultural change.  This course examines the role of horror films in expressing anxieties about events such as the two World Wars, the Great Depression, the Cold War, the sexual revolution, and the AIDS crisis.  Anticipated screenings include Freaks, Mamoulian's Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, Rosemary's Baby, The Devil, and The Rocky Horror Picture Show, accompanied by lecture and discussion.

course.course_name: Topics in American Cinema: Hollywood Through a Documentary Lens
course.course_description: Spend part of your summer behind the scenes, watching the best (and coolest) documentaries ever made about filmmaking, and the Hollywood way. Learn what life is like in the belly of the beast ... who tamed it, and who was tamed by it. Studying the working process of such artists as Francis Coppola, Werner Herzog, Terry Gilliam, John Ford, and Orson Welles, we will learn to appreciate the myriad documentary techniques that tell these often larger-than-life tales. In-class screenings include "Hearts of Darkness," "The Kid Stays in the Picture," "Burden of Dreams," and "A Personal Journey with Martin Scorsese Through American Movies"--masterworks of documentary in and of themselves, exploring the nature and vision of narrative cinema in spellbinding ways. The first commandment of documentary filmmaking is finding a great subject. For film lovers, what can be more fascinating than Hollywood, from its allure to its limitations?

course.course_name: Topics in American Cinema: Film Comedy
course.course_description: A high-minded exploration of a sometimes-lowbrow art. Quintessentially American ideas of social mobility, freedom to satirize, and celebration of the underdog -- to name just a few -- have helped Anglo-American and immigrant artists to produce a unique brand of filmed comedy, from Mack Sennett to Preston Sturges and Judd Apatow. This course examines the rich tapestry of the American film comedy, and the social, historical, and technological factors that made it possible, from its birth in silent cinema to the present. Films to be screened and discussed include (but are not limited to): Modern Times, Duck Soup, The Apartment, The Graduate, Annie Hall, and Animal House.

course.course_name: Topics In American Cinema: Film Noir
course.course_description: Fee: $75. Whether considered a genre, a style, a mood or a post-war cycle, the Film Noir of the 40s and 50s continues to fascinate for its broodingly dark (morally and cinematographically) view of humankind.  Countering the war-time spirit of can-do optimism, these low-budget movies--with their convoluted narratives and voice-over--reflect a shift toward inwardness and existential doubt.  Films include Double Indemnity, Laura, Gilda, and Out of the Past.

course.course_name: Interdisciplinary Studies in Film: Film & Politics
course.course_description: The power of the state is arguably the ultimate "social antagonist" faced by any dramatic character, from Titus in Shakespeare's earliest tragedy, "Titus Andronicus," to Joe Frady in Alan Pakula's "The Parallax View." This course will study protagonists from such films as "All The King's Men," "Wag the Dog," "All the President's Men, and "The Great Dictator"--who lead us into the labyrinths of power politics, humanizing them even as they risk being devoured by the Minotaur of the mass mind. Politics can be anathema to selfhood.  Crowds can erase individual conscience in an instant and leave shattered worlds in their wake.  But whether political protagonists ultimately serve the state's ends, defy them, or are destroyed by them, they provide a means for psychic survival in an increasingly polarized world. Among additional films for screening and discussion are "Z," "The Killing Fields," "Under Fire," "13 Days," & "The Diary of Anne Frank."  Books include Elias Canetti's "Crowds and Power."

Adaptation is a reflex of mind. We see what we read and we read what we see: therein lies the power and the peril of reiteration, form-to-form. This course will explore the basic elements of that process, from life to script to screen. We will begin by looking at more traditional adaptations, such as The Quiet American and To Kill A Mockingbird, then probe some variations on source texts, e.g. Dangerous Liaisons and Valmont, The Big Clock and No Way Out, and Romeo and Juliet, as directed by George Cukor and by Baz Luhrmann. We will explore issues of point-of-view and a film's voice, as exemplified by Burgess and Kubrick's A Clockwork Orange, and then delve into the singular example of The Diving Bell and the Butterfly, a rare double-embedment of a protagonist s personal adaptation to crisis expressed as a book and, in turn, as a film. Through close reading, screening and discussion, we will visit the subjective realms of the adaptation process---the art of remaining faithful to a source's story, yet playful with its interpretation.

course.course_name: Inside the Box: The History of Writing for Television
course.course_description: Television squeezed the cinematic arts into a box the size of a footstool. Hollywood thought that TV was The Enemy but a new generation of writers, actors and directors was breaking in to American homes in a way that was radically more intimate than movies had ever been.  Since that “Golden Age of Television,” the medium has gone from the sublime to the ridiculous and back again, from Paddy Chayefsky to “The Gong Show” to David Simon with many lighter moments in between.  And while serious journalism withers, TV drama is adapting the terms of the novel to the travails of democracy itself.  While the 21st Century looms with perils unknown, television keeps us laughing in ever more sophisticated ways.  The Box is our society in a nutshell and its writers are now members of the American family. This course will look at how they have been looking at us.

Fee: $75. A survey of American TV history, with a focus on dramatic narration related to independent cinema. Structured in three acts--from the "Golden Age" of the 1950s to the dramatic complexity found in recent Cable series--it begins with prestigious writers Rod Serling and Paddy Chayefsky; studies groundbreaking mini-series like "Roots" and "Holocaust"; and explores how shows such as "Hill Street Blues" and "Twin Peaks" laid the groundwork for HBO series including "Oz," "The Sopranos," "The Wire," and"Six Feet Under."  Producing 13-week dramas over the span of years, these programs have developed a sophisticated narrative form, borrowing from as well as informing cinematic storytelling.

The course will examine and practice screen adaptation through lectures, assignments, and workshop discussions.  The guiding questions for the course:  How does film narrative differ from prose narrative?  What transformations, accommodations, and outright trickery is required to render a preexisting narrative into a screenplay?  Each student will choose a short story and in the course of the workshop you will adapt the short story twice:  once "faithfully", and once with license.

A workshop in feature film writing. Students enter the course with a story idea, ready to start a feature screenplay. The first few sessions will be dedicated to refining your treatment/outlines and discussing story. Those who are prepared to start presenting scenes are encouraged to do so. The remainder of the seminar will be devoted to reading and critiquing screenplay pages. Through lectures and workshop discussions, the course will examine the details of character development and scene construction. Completing a draft screenplay will be the goal of the seminar; at minimum students will be expected to complete a fully conceived and revised first act, with the second well in hand. This course will emphasize the role of criticism today. We will screen films, from classics to some currently in theaters. We will read, analyze and evaluate critical responses to them considering some crucial questions: How does criticism hold up over time? How do you approach a new film? How do you approach one that has been written about for decades? Students will write short reviews and longer essays with an eye toward developing a personal voice. This course assumes there is no right or wrong in criticism, just stronger or weaker arguments, and we’ll focus on ways to create the best case for your original ideas. (Syllabus posted on CW). course.course_name: Film Theory I: From the Origins To Mitry
course.course_description: Prerequisite: FILM W3001. Fee: $50. An introduction to classical film theory, from its beginnings to the early structuralist work of Christian Metz.

This class will provide an introductory overview of contemporary film theory and philosophy, focusing in particular on cinema’s relation to media, technology and culture. Film theory has tended to take the projected live-action narrative feature film as its object, but increasingly new forms of technology are transforming the ways we perceive and interact with moving images.  How is cinema changing in the age of computer and digital technologies?  How have the most influential theories of film, media and culture over the last half-century provided ways of understanding these changes?

Course content changes yearly. Krzysztof Kieslowski created some of the most philosophically and stylistically rich films of the 1980s and 90s.  We explore such works as “The Decalogue” and “Three Colors: Blue, White, Red” in the context of post-war Polish cinema, and do close analysis of his films in conjunction with their screenplays. Fee: $50.

course.course_description: By presenting 12 full feature films and clips from many others, the course examines the 50-year career of Clint Eastwood. From his beginnings as a studio contract player, he has been a popular television star, an icon of Italian cinema, a Hollywood superstar, a successful producer, and the most respected of American auteurs. In addition to in-depth study of films like Mystic River and Midnight in the Garden of Good & Evil, the course will explore the evolution and appeal of his "Man With No Name" and "Dirty Harry" characters.

A survey of the history of producing in the U.S. from pre-Hollywood filmmaking to the poststudio era of independent producers, agency packaging, and industry conglomerates. Hollywood producers such as Thomas Ince, Jesse Lasky, Irving Thalberg, David O. Selznick, and Dore Schary are considered. Emphasis is also placed on independent productions as an alternative method of filmmaking.

Most writers find a deadline to be a crucial in completing a project, and screenwriters are no different.  In this class, students write a feature-length screenplay in twelve weeks.  Although there will be discussion of the craft of screenwriting and of work in progress, the emphasis here is on producing script pages under strict deadlines.  Students MUST complete a script within the six-week time limit in order to get a grade for this course.

course.course_description: Open only to first-year M.F.A. candidates in Film. Corequisites: FILM R6037 and R6095. Students explore the grammatical rules and narrative elements of cinematic storytelling by completing a minimum of three short, nondialogue exercises and two sound exercises, all shot and edited in video. Emphasizes using the camera as an articulate narrator to tell a coherent, grammatically correct, engaging, and cinematic story. Technical workshops on camera, lighting, sound, and editing accompany the workshops, as well as lectures that provide a methodology for the director.

course.course_description: This workshop explores directing technique giving special attention to methods derived from Constantin Stanislavski.  Following the precept that acting is doing, students will explore the actors craft from within to create truthful and specific performances.  Directors will be introduced to practical tools for creating organic, moment-to-moment work.  Connection exercises flow into an exploration of improvisation and in-depth scene work.  Each week students will select, cast and present scenes from published screenplays for in-class discussion and analysis.
